|ftname=Battleships of Germany |topic=war |dykdate=6 March 2009 |dykentry=... that the '''[[Nassau class battleship|''Nassau''-class battleship]]s''' laid down in 1907 were the first class of [[German Empire|German]] [[dreadnought]]s built in response to the British {{HMS|Dreadnought|1906|6}}? |currentstatus=FA |four=no }} {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Ships|class=FA}} {{WPMILHIST|class=FA|A-Class=pass|Maritime=yes|German=yes|WWI=yes|OMT=1}} {{WikiProject Germany|class=FA|importance=low}} }}
== Design aspects ==
Some information from Ireland, Bernard, ''Jane's Battleships of the 20th Century'', p. 30, ISBN 0004709977, which may make the article more comprehensive: *length-to-breadth ration was 5.45, "comparatively stubby" (even for a battleship); *wing turrets and trunks were very close to side, necessitating extra width; they were vulnerable and made it difficult to provide longitudinal anti-torpedo bulkheads; *main armament squeezed into machinery spaces, but had benefit of dividing those spaces into three, increasing survivability; *given the overall weight of the main and secondary armament (14% of total displacement), turrets had to be sited as low as possible for stability purposes; secondary armament, lower down in casemates at main deck level, were of doubtful use in a seaway; *Nassau could fire six guns forward, six aft, and eight in broadside, the same as the (theoretical) figures for contemporary rival ''Dreadnought'', but Nassaus required two more rifles to do so; *armour belt was 12" only in limited area in centre.
And here is some interesting information on the roll characteristics, from Lyon, Hugh, ''The Encyclopedia of the World's Warships'', pp. 100â€“01, ISBN 051722478X: *the wide beam and heavy wing turrets gave them a large [[metacentric height]]. This ordinarily would have made them stable gun platforms, but their roll period proved to coincide with that of the average North Sea swell. The bilge keels were added to mitigate this. [[User:Kablammo|Kablammo]] ([[User talk:Kablammo|talk]]) 16:17, 5 April 2009 (UTC)
